@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 @cecilthesheep For reasons that parallel the reasons y'all have given in this conversation. But those practical arguments don't answer the moral question—at most they show that the moral question is, as a practical matter, irrelevant.

@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 @cecilthesheep Yeah but "if you're representing a super awful murderer, is it morally good to do a good job?" is, at least to me, an interesting moral question too. It's not an interesting professional ethics question: the answer is obviously yes...

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep What I am trying to figure out is if you reject, as @cecilthesheep does, the idea that one person can in principle deserve lifesaving care more than another person does. Until just now I thought you were agreeing with Cecil.
@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep So it's not so much "Bob deserves it just as much as Adam does" but rather "what if we're wrong"?

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep I understand why, as a practical matter, you do not want healthcare providers making that decision. But purely as a moral question, I don't understand why raising the stakes changes the underlying structure of who deserves what.

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep So we agree that people can deserve things, and we share the intuition that someone who creates his own plight deserves assistance slightly less than someone suffering through no fault of his own. What I don't understand is why making it a life-or-death situation changes things.
@OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep @Cac0110 Because I think hard moral questions are interesting and worth talking about in their own right
@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 @cecilthesheep Nope. They'll both drink it and get exactly the same benefit from it
@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep I know. I'm looking for a point of common ground here

@OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep @Cac0110 I get that, I really do. And I appreciate that there are very good reasons for way professional ethics works in health care. What I'm trying to do here is separate out the moral question from the professional-ethics question

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep Adam is thirsty because he hasn't been able to get any water. Bob is thirsty because he got some water and then willfully dumped it on the ground. They're not dying, just uncomfortable. You have enough water for one person. Do we agree that Adam deserves the water more than Bob?
@cecilthesheep @Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile That's consistent

@cecilthesheep @Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile And the question is, all else equal, can we say that one person deserves care more than another, even while granting that they both deserve it? I think we can.

@cecilthesheep @Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile No, she doesn't deserve to be turned away. The entire premise here is that nobody deserves to be turned away but somebody is going to be turned away anyway. ...
@cecilthesheep @Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile But would you agree with me that other than in that context, we can meaningfully talk about who deserves what?
@OptimeTheophile @cecilthesheep @Cac0110 To be clear, are you saying we can't say "x deserves y" outside the healthcare context too?

@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 This is an important practical point against that sort of triage, but it doesn't get at the question of whether someone who is willfully unvaccinated has the same moral claim on scarce COVID care resources as someone vaccinated

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile When I say "they caused it," I mean that they chose not to take a vaccine that is tremendously effective at preventing the situation they now find themselves in. I'm not particularly interested in whether they subjectively believed they were acting morally by doing so

@cecilthesheep @Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile What about the implication that one person deserves more of a particular scarce resource? Because if we can't say that we can't say anyone deserves anything more than another person does
@2_trenchcoat As a purely moral question, why?
@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 But a much narrower analysis—e.g. "did you cause this exact problem for no good reason" is workable, and I don't see the moral problem with it.

@OptimeTheophile @Cac0110 I don't think you have to approach it thoroughly. In fact, I think you shouldn't. Nobody has the right to look at another person's whole life and decide where they fall on the spectrum of healthcare desert. ...
@2_trenchcoat Are you saying this as a matter of professional ethics or morality?

@Cac0110 @OptimeTheophile I agree that under normal conditions it would be wrong to deny someone healthcare on the basis that they don't deserve it. Everyone deserves care. But when resource constraints mean not everyone can get care, why is it a violation of human dignity to consider desert?

@OptimeTheophile I think even as a matter of "this person deserves it more, so all else equal they should get the hospital bed," triage on vaccination status is permissible. I understand that as a matter of professional ethics and practicality that may not work.

I don't think it would be immoral to triage by vaccination status. And it seems like nobody else does either, since the standard response is to make a slippery-slope argument rather than defend the position that the unvaccinated deserve to be treated just like the vaccinated.

Example: Box A has 10 gold. Box B has 1 gold, 9 silver. Box C has 10 silver. If you picked gold, it's very likely that you have Box A and therefore will draw another gold next.

@JustinLawGuy @YachtieLaw The prior probability of A is 0.5. 
Probability of drawing a gold ball if you have box A is 1. 
Probability of drawing a gold ball across both boxes is 0.75 . 
Bayes' theorem gives us 67% chance that you have Box A.
